title: Understanding Redox Behavior in STCH Water Splitters using In Situ Monochromated EELS and Atomic Resolution EDS
content: Due to ever increasing energy needs, alternative, renewable solar fuel generating processes are being investigated to reduce environmental impact, reduce cost, and improve efficacy of green technologies, including solar thermochemical hydrogen production (STCH) [1]. In exemplar STCH materials a metal oxide is thermally reduced, releasing O2 and generating oxygen vacancies (VO) in the crystal lattice, followed by a re-oxidation step in steam resulting in H2 gas formation as the water molecule is split into H2 and O to filling VO formed during reduction [2]. Recently, our group, using a machine learning model applied to the Materials Project database, predicted an orthorhombic spinel (Bb21m) BaFe2O4 (BFO) shown in Fig. 3a. to be a successful water splitting material [3]. We evaluated water splitting behavior of BFO using a stagnation flow reactor (SFR) showing promising results. However, an irreversible phase transformation at low oxygen partial pressure (pO2) rendered the material unstable to repeat cycling. To prevent the irreversible phase transformation, Al was substituted for Fe in BFO. The resultant Al-doped BaAl0.4Fe1.6O4 (BAFO) with a hexagonal (P63) structure shown in Fig. 3b was synthesized and had increased stability at low pO2 and high temperature, enabling greater H2 production.
